This doesn't seem right -- I must've been comparing to PS1 or PS2 and not the Base.

If the policy check fails, you zero out the host_name -- but the default for that policy is admin_or_owner, so the host_name will be exposed to the owner, who could be a non-admin.  So I don't think this addresses the bug.

Also -- Jeremy's point is that you could expose this info to a non-admin user by hashing the host name with sha256 or something.  That way, the end user could tell that volumes are on different hosts, but not be able to tell what the actual host name is.  (But while nova has a use case for that, I don't think cinder does.)

I realize it's too late to do anything about this, but just so you keep this in mind for next time ... Take a look at this page:

https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/cinder/ussuri.html#relnotes-16-0-0-stable-ussuri-bug-fixes

Your release note is munged in with everyone else.  So if you don't mention netapp ontap, it won't be clear what backend this release note applies to.  I suggest prefacing your note with

   NetApp ONTAP: Fixed bug ...

that way, NetApp  users can find the bugfixes relevant to them more easily.  Unfortunately, we don't have a way to group all the NetApp fixes together (unless you want to do some hacking on reno).

Mingyuan - you missed the point I was trying to make in my previous comment.  You are proposing changes to a system database.  During software upgrade that database will need to be migrated from the old version to the new version.  That means that this change impacts software update.

The sysinv db is using sqlalchemy migrate method to modify the schema of tables in db, which means any schema modification to the db is a patch to be applied. That resolves the dynamic change of the db during the update.

Please describe how sysinv will be treating these edgeworker nodes once they are in the inventory. Will sysinv be providing DHCP services for these nodes? Can the nodes be locked/unlocked, upgraded, etc...? If not, will additional semantic checks be required to prevent these functions?
Added additional description for this

I think you need a discussion here of kubernetes version compatibility (see https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/version-skew-policy). What will be the restrictions on the kubernetes version running on each edgeworker node? How would an upgrade of the kubernetes version on the starlingx platform affect the edgeworker node and vice versa?
I split the descript into 2 sections, line 165 addresses the version aligment during deployment process, while upgrade issue is described in Upgrade Impact part.
Do we have the version requires for those two Linux distributions?
We propose to support most versions in general but will have only one or two LTS versions verified as reference.
Which parts of this would be done with ansible? Would there be one playbook or multiple playbooks? How will differences in the linux distro on the edgeworker hosts be handled?
All the process are done with one playbook. the playbook will choose the right distribution repo and package management tool base on the ansible facts of the nodes.

I wish I could think of a better term for this type of worker.
i.e. it's not really specific to an edge node.

As you say below, in the long term, this is simply a worker node whose OS is not managed/installed by StarlingX.

The idea of changing StarlingX to be installable as an application on top of an existing OS installation has been discussed as a potential long term direction within StarlingX.  The thinking here is to get StarlingX out of the business of supporting the hosts' kernel ... maintaining CVEs, etc. .

So arguably this is the general worker node of the future.

... but can't think of a good name for this.
e.g. non-dedicated-worker node, external-worker node, standalone-worker node, ... don't like any of these.

Naming these nodes is critical and hard.  We have struggled to come up with a good name.
Something like "limited-worker" or "user-managed-worker" would highlight the difference in functionality but aren't great names.  I think I am good with edgeworker for now until someone comes up with a better name.  We should make it very clear in the documentation what can be done with these nodes and what isn't done by Starlingx for them.
I agree

I got your point, but even we call all the hosts 'worker' node, there should still be a 'normal' worker node with verified centos(rt kernel as well) installed from scratch, right? If it is the case, then an additional parameter/sub-function will be added to distinguish the normal worker node or the one that StarlingX does not manage the OS.

The term edgeworker derives from the worker node that is much closer to the edge devices.

So I also suggest that we clearly descript here the other difference between 'edgeworker' and 'worker' is the 'edgeworker' is much closer to the edge devices than 'worker' nodes.  I think that is also important to the user to understand why StarlingX wants to manage this new kind of node.
Done

I am wondering whether a safer way to introduce this is to model this as something OTHER than the sysinv 'host' object.

As mentioned, this  is significantly different than an existing host, in the sense that StarlingX does not install the OS and installs/configures Kubernetes differently on this edge worker.

By NOT having it as a 'host'object, it means that we don't have to find EVERY spot in existing StarlingX code and make sure it handles this new personality type correctly.


... and you could still provide some UI/CLI/API integration 
e.g. Horizon - Inventory page could show both 'host' tables and 'edge worker' tables
CLI/RESTAPI - system host-list ... could show a table of both or integrated table

One main principle of the proposal is to leverage existing StarlingX manageability as much as possible, not trying to make the wheels in another way and integrate to StarlingX.

We think the most valuable and core services of StarlingX are the flock services. These services are all working around the entity 'host'. 

From the code complexity perspective, yes, modifiying the model will need a bunch of modification, testing and verification. However, from project development perspective, we need to make StarlingX demonstrate the unique ability to meet users need. Obviously, creating or integrating a solution to manage edgeworker nodes other than sysinv/flock is not the case we want because this won't bring StarlingX any advantages comparing to other projects.

We'd rather choose making the effort to strengthen the flock services, for StarlingX's future development consideration.

I think Greg has a point here, Mingyuan.  Edge workers can still be in sysinv (and in the other flock services) but maybe as a different object than the "host" object. I'm not sure which approach would be the best, but I ask you to consider Greg's suggestion.

I would think we would not want to support an edge worker on the internal private management network.  

Given it is running a NON-StarlingX OS, it is a bit of a security risk to deploy it on the internal private management network.

Also, long term view is that edge workers are connected over L3 anyways ... might as well start with them NOT on the management network.

That is a good point, I think there should be a new logical network like 'extended management network' or 'edge management network' whatever it is called to separatly manage the edgeworker nodes.

Adding that network will need a separate spec for further description, I suppose in phase three. We'll keep edgeworker managed in management network before that happen, but won't turn edgeworker node support on to the public announcement until we addressed all the security concerns.

An alternative to consider ...

When we were starting to look at this again, after doing the raspberry pi demo at OpenStack Summit, we were actually looking at managing these types of nodes from Kubernetes.
I.e. 
- introducing Kubernetes CRDs for these new nodes to hold the configuration data wrt these nodes, 
- introducing a Kubernetes Operator / Controller for managing the state-machine and sequencing of reconciling the interaction with these nodes ... e.g. the installation and configuration of kubernetes on these nodes, the joining of the nodes to the StarlingX Cluster, etc. .
- and,
   using the CRD/Kubernetes-Operator plugin functionality to deal with nodes of different types (e.g. ubuntu-based vs centos-based)


It's a more "cloud native" approach to doing this.

And as a transition, could again still integrate the Horizon - Inventory page to show hosts and these edge worker CRDs, etc. 




The downside of the ANSIBLE playbook approach is that these actions can not be done remotely over a REST API.

Would be better to either support these pre-installed-OS-hosts as new objects in StarlingX Data Model ... or as Kubernetes CRD ... .

As a matter of fact, we have that CRD/Operator prototype implemented as well.
I agree with the idea of cloud native ways. But the ansible playbook is still needed as the implementation of the Operators operations.
Like:

- kubelet/containerd installation
- Host add/update
- Network configuration
- etc...

The Operator helps break the whole playbook apart into different sections of CRD.

For the data model, as I mentioned, we believe the flock services are the core advantages of STX. In another word, if we created CRD and Operator without interaction with STX data model, why users choose StarlingX? There are tons of projects claiming they have a full manageability of Kubernetes clusters.

This isn't the only documentation change needed. Any doc that mentions "worker" nodes may have to change.  Installation and configuration guide changes may be needed.  In fact we may need entirely new install/config docs.  Plus we need to very clearly call out the limitations of these nodes.

specs/name-based-endpoints.rst.message:
This could be reworded slightly to make it clearer why we might want to use name-based endpoints:

The problem(s) we are trying to solve is...

Name-based endpoints solve this problem by...
I see. I did some changes. Let me know if it is clearer now.

I think we have two separate use cases here:

1. An API FQDN used by all endpoints that resolves to multiple IP addresses, possibly in different broadcast domains
2. Endpoints that use different FQDNs for different services

So 1. could work with paths?

These two could be combined, with separate endpoint FQDNs that each resolve to multiple IPs?

I am not sure if 1. would work. When a server name is solved to different IPs, the client has to handle that. I mean, the client would get the list, and try one by one. It is not an actual health check, and the service might look ok (accepting connection on port 80/443) when they are not ready to handle requests.

Moreover, I am not sure if the IP list returned by the DNS server could rotate somehow based on load (or other factors). Otherwise, we would always hit the first server, while the rest would sit there idle.
For those not so familiar with consul, what does it provide over HAProxy?

It is not a replacement, but an addition. 
I see, I will add more details about it.

That results in lb with listener in offline state, blocking all the traffic.
I guess this could be moved out of the condition.
Actually, it has to be there in case, new_sgs is None and there is no SG on LB, it will blow up on line 185.

I thought about moving it out to line 173 as the supposed default value for the sgs should be an empty list, it can make things more clear.

But no strong opinion.

```
&Doc=project:openstack/releases+file:^doc/.*+NOT+file:^tools/.*+NOT+file:^openstack_releases/.*
&Data=project:openstack/releases+file:^data/.*
```

Also I added the `Extended Maintainance` section, I don't know if we could retrieve this info but I think it could be worth to add it too to avoid to lets the number of section grow-up and to highlight EOL things as EM are not released they will appear under this section. 

```
&Extended+Maintainance=((project:openstack/releases+file:^deliverables/rocky/.*+is:open+NOT+label:Workflow-1)+OR+(project:openstack/releases+file:^deliverables/queens/.*+is:open+NOT+label:Workflow-1)+OR+(project:openstack/releases+file:^deliverables/pike/.*+is:open+NOT+label:Workflow-1)+OR+(project:openstack/releases+file:^deliverables/ocata/.*+is:open+NOT+label:Workflow-1
``` 

What do you think about these sections?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/758378/8/doc/source/reference/reviewer_guide.rst

The Doc and Data content are already covered by the Other section. I don't think those are really big enough areas to need separate sections.

Extended Maintenance I don't think we should have. Once a project enters EM, that means the release team is done with them. They will show up in the All section below, but we should not receive anything for there. And I believe our validation test should fail because of the branch status, so if someone were to propose a release for an EM branch, they should find out and know to abandon it without us needing to watch for those.

neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall.message: +1, we have done some works to avoid using NORMAL flows, it can cause high CPU load of vswitchd when there are unknow dst MAC packets. Some bugs had described such behaivor as flood, ovs will send the packet to all ports under the same segment domain including those ports which have no local vlan.

That will forward to all OVS port some kind of traffic, like  multicast https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4541#section-2.1.2

Another reason to use explicit output was the performance.

I would suggest, to keep the previous behavior and performance, to add a new config knob or read "baremetal_smartnic" (actually I prefer not to add a new config option)

this seems hyper fragile. Can we generate config using templates at put the required config in /etc/multipath/conf.d?

Which looks to be enabled by default according to the manpage?

https://www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/5-multipath.conf/

The challenge, as I think you can see in the manpage, is the file format is complex and there are a lot of potential things (many obscure) you can tune. Downstream, my team is aware that a lot of customers need to apply vendor specific tuning based on the overcloud hardware. Conversely, there are very few settings they need to control via THT parameters. This creates the fine line I'm trying to walk. I could generate the "easy" settings from a template, but merging the custom stuff that the user supplies would be awkward.

Given that this file structure isn't exactly as simple as an INI, would it be better to use a template to generate it or perhaps some other tool to modify an existing one? I'm not certain lineinfile will scale
Yikes, indeed. My team has been circling this ring of purgatory for many releases. Thanks for understanding :-/
I'll go with -> yikes.  :D if it works for you ok. The alternative would be to write a custom python module to parse/fixup the file instead which might be better testable, etc.

There are two requirements that are somewhat conflicting. On one side there's the need to control a small number of options (find_multipaths, skip_kpartx and user_friendly_names), and this could easily be done by generating multipath.conf from a template.

The second requirement is where things get tricky. It's very common for real world (i.e. downstream) deployments to require complex custom settings that are specific to the overcloud hardware. Often, the hardware vendor provides a set of recommended settings. This makes it difficult to generate multipath.conf from a template. There's also a need to handle upgrades, where the overcloud node has a preexisting multipath.conf file. That's why the patch supports the ability to inherit a preexisting multipath.conf file, as well as a "bring your own" custom file.

So I discovered this won't work in earlier releases (e.g. train), when ansible is invoked from a mistral container. Basically, the ansible controller won't be able to access the src. I have a redesign in mind.

This all should be in an action plugin rather than trying to do it in ansible. It's way more efficient and unit testable.  Here's an example of an action plugin that runs remote commands:

https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-operator-ansible/src/branch/master/plugins/action/timestamp_file.py#L111-L167

Alternatively you could use a  module to invoke all this on the remote system but I think you can get away with an action plugin instead.

modifying just the `filter` param is not be enough on CentOS 7/RHEL7 as by default lvmetad is enabled (`use_lvmetad=1`) and lvmetad uses the parameter `global_filter` instead of `filter` so when system boots up lvmetad will still scan block devices which belongs to guests unless they are filtered in `global_filter`

We can add same config in devices/global_filter as well to avoid this.

Reference : https://access.redhat.com/solutions/3213311
The other benefit is unit tests, https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-operator-ansible/src/branch/master/tests/plugins/action/test_timestamp_file.py

Did you consider diffing this list against devices which are on the running system (e.g. output of lsblk) and keeping only the intersection (and then adding those in tripleo_tripleo_lvmfilter_devices_whitelist)?

I suggest this because I tested this in my env which has a standard compute and a standard ceph-storage node. The ceph node has /dev/sdb which is used as an OSD. The compute node does not have /dev/sdb. I put nothing in the whitelist. The compute node had the following in its lvm.conf

global_filter=["a|/dev/sdb|","r|.*|"]

So even though /dev/sdb didn't exist on my compute node, it ended up in the list. This doesn't break anything but seems an unnecessary side effect.

Maybe you encountered this type of thing in your testing too, but determined you needed to keep it for some reason?

I agree that it doesn't feel right to include ceph devices in the filter applied to non-ceph nodes. It may be benign when the device doesn't exist (/dev/sdb in John's example), but what happens if it ~does~ exist, and it's associated with a vm that we *do* want to filter.

My testing of this patch after the intersect was added indicates that the intersect worked the way we had intended (reduce the list to nothing) but it still resulted in my system attempting to add an empty filter like this:

        global_filter=["","r|.*|"]

This made the handler fail and thus the deployment failed. This doesn't mean we should remove the intersect (it's working). The intersect exposed a new bug which is that if for whatever reason the allowed_list is empty, then we shouldn't go forward with installing a filter.

No, it doesn't. The existing ones have to be removed before the command to generate new ones, otherwise it will reuse the existing ones.
OK - so "kubeadm init phase certs" won't replace the files if they exist?

> Why is this necessary? Add a comment. Why do the move vs. a copy?

To back them up in case the following kubeadm fails. If not using mv, we've have to copy and then remove these two files for the "kubeadm init phase certs ..." to regenerate them.
